title.text: When Frequency Data Meet Dispersion Data in the Extraction of Multi-word Units from a Corpus: A Study of Trigrams in Chinese

abstractContent.text: One of the main approaches to extract multi-word units is the frequency threshold approach, but the way this approach considers dispersion data still leaves a lotto be desired.
This study adopts Gries's (2008) dispersion measure to extract trigrams from a Chinese corpus, and the results are compared with those of the frequency threshold approach.
It is found that the overlap between the two approaches is not very large.
This demonstrates the necessity of taking dispersion data more seriously and the dynamic nature of lexical representations.
Moreover, the trigrams extracted in the present study can be used in a wide range of language resources in Chinese.

introductionContent.text: In the past decades, multi-word units have been of great interest not only to corpus linguists but also to cognitive linguists and psycholinguists.

It has been empirically demonstrated that multi-word units are pervasive in our languages (cf.), and they are considered psychologically real when it is found that a language learner starts with formulaic phrases that serve specific functions (e.g.,.
One of the current approaches to extract multi-word units is the frequency threshold approach (cf..
The frequency threshold approach reflects the argument that frequently used items are more entrenched in our mind.

While many have recognized that frequency data are more useful when complemented with dispersion data (e.g.,, the way the frequency threshold approach considers the dispersion of a multi-word unit still leaves a lotto be desired.
For example, when automatically extracting multi-word units in English, simply set a dispersion threshold, i.e., occurring in at least five corpus texts.
Therefore, the present study aims to probe more deeply into the interaction between the frequency data and the dispersion data of multi-word units.
Both a frequency-based set of multi-word units and a dispersion-based set are automatically extracted from a Chinese corpus, and the two sets are compared.
The present study adopts a more scientific method to compute the dispersion of a multi-word unit, i.e., the DP value.
This method is argued to be more flexible, simple, extendable, and sensitive than previous methods.
Note that given the limited resources, the present study focuses on three-word units (trigrams for short, hereafter).
The paper is organized as follows.
Section 2 introduces the method of the present study.
Section 4 is a general discussion of the findings and the implications.
Section 5 highlights the contributions of the findings.
